In vitro investigation of the influence of nano-cellulose on starch andmilk digestion and mineral adsorption
Lingling Liu a, Fanbin Kong b,⁎ a Department of Food Science and Human Nutrition, Iowa State University, Ames, IA, 50010, United States of America b Department of Food Science and Technology, University of Georgia, Athens, GA 30602, United States of America
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: fkong@uga.edu (F. Kong).

Article history: Received 30 May 2019 Received in revised form 18 June 2019 Accepted 24 June 2019 Available online 02 July 2019
Three types of nanocellulose, namely nano-fibrilated cellulose (NFC, also called cellulose nano-fibrils (CNF)), TEMPO (2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl radical) oxidized cellulose nano-fibrils (TEMPO-CNF), and nanocrystalline cellulose (NCC, also called cellulose nano-crystals (CNC)), were studied in terms of their effects on in vitromilk digestion andmineral adsorption. The effects of anionic NC (TEMPO-CNF and CNC) on in vitro starch digestion and glucose diffusion were also investigated. Results show that TEMPO-CNF and CNC at high concentrations caused significant reductions in glucose diffusion, especially at 0.36% (w/w) TEMPO-CNF and 2–4% (w/ w) CNC. In addition, CNF and TEMPO-CNF at 0.30% (w/w) significantly reduced the amount of free fatty acid produced during intestinal digestion ofmilk fat. CNC at a concentration of 0.3% (w/w)delayed diffusion of free amino nitrogen during intestinal digestion of milk protein. All three types of NC adsorbed significant amount of Fe, and CNC adsorbed significant amount of Zn, while no significant adsorption was observed on otherminerals (Ca, Mg, Zn, Cu and Ag). Results from this study suggest that all three types of NC, when incorporated in food or supplements as zero-calorie fiber, may affect food digestion and nutrient absorption.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nanocellulose (NC) is defined as a family of nano-scaled cellulosic materials with at least one dimension b100 nm. NC is prepared through mechanical shearing, acid/enzymatic hydrolysis of cellulosic materials or biosynthesis which renders NC hydrogel behavior [1–4]. This hydrogel may resemble gelling properties similar to some viscous dietary fiber. Due to its viscous property, large specific surface area, negligible toxicity, low density, biodegradability, and biocompatibility, NC has been applied in a number offields, including textile, pharmaceutics, cosmetics, and packaging [5–10]. Among the most studied nanocellulosic materials are three types of NC, including nano-fibrillated cellulose (NFC, also called cellulose nano-fibrils (CNF)), TEMPO (2,2,6,6- tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl radical) oxidized CNF (TEMPO-CNF), and nano-crystalline cellulose (NCC, also called cellulose nano-crystals (CNC)), which vary in fiber length, diameter, surface charge and rheological properties. Specifically, TEMPO oxidation reduces the energy consumption required for the nano-fibrillation process and converts primary hydroxyl groups of cellulose to carboxyl groups [11,12]. CNC is often prepared by acid hydrolysis thus carries negative surface charge. When prepared from sulfuric acid, CNC carries sulfate ester group [4].
As a nanoscale fiber, it has become of interest to investigate if NC possesses similar effects as dietary fiber (DF) towards food digestion and nutrient absorption. The presence of dietary fiber prolongs the transit time of food in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract, promotes satiation, and improves satiety. DF can increase digesta viscosity, delay gastric emptying as well as slow down digestion and nutrient transport. It has been reported that a high-fiber diet can improve gastrointestinal health, glucose tolerance, and insulin response, and enhance satiety feeling thus benefiting weight loss. DF has also been known to reduce hyperlipidemia, hypertension, coronary heart disease risks and some cancers [13]. On the other hand, some studies have shown that dietary fibers may impair mineral absorption in the small intestine due to their binding and/or sequestering effects [14].
Our previous studies have shown that CNF at high concentrations significantly retarded glucose diffusion during in vitro starch digestion [15]. Moreover, the effects of nanocellulose on in vitro lipid and protein digestion have been investigatedwhere results show that all three types of nanocellulose (CNF, TEMPO-CNF and CNC) delayed lipid digestion and the diffusion of free amino nitrogen (FAN) at high NC concentrations [16,17]. However, limited research [18,19] is available on how CNC and TEMPO-CNF influence starch digestion and glucose absorption. Furthermore, very few studies have been carried out on the interaction between NC and food matrix, such as milk, in human GI tract as well as the effect of NC on food digestion and mineral absorption. Among the limited studies [20,21], the research focuses were on the effects of CNF
or CNC on protein-stabilized lipid emulsions or high fatty foods. Thus, the objectives of this study were to investigate 1) the influence of TEMPO-CNF and CNC on in vitro starch digestion and glucose diffusion, and 2) the influence of three types of NC onmilk digestion and mineral adsorption under simulated gastrointestinal conditions.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
Nanofibrillated cellulose (3% (w/w) inwater)was obtained from the Process Development Center at the University of Maine (Orono, ME). TEMPO-based cellulose nano-fibrils (1.1 wt% in water, 1.5 mmolCOONa/g dry CNF) and cellulose nanocrystals (10.8 wt% in water, 0.94 wt% sulfur on dry CNC, sodium form) were both obtained from the USDA's Forest Products Laboratory (Madison, Wisconsin). CNF was produced from bleached softwood kraft pulp via an ultrafine grinder (Masuko MKZB15-50J supermass colloider) which created a high shear zone to liberate nanocellulose. TEMPO-CNF and CNC were prepared via TEMPO oxidation and sulfuric acid hydrolysis respectively [22,23]. The nominal sizes of CNF, TEMPO-CNF, and CNC materials were the following: CNF (width of 50 nm and length up to several hundred microns), TEMPO-CNF (width of ~20 nm and length up to 2 μm) and CNC (~5 nm width and 150 nm length). According to our previous test, the zeta potential of the three nanomaterials dissolved in 1 mM PBS (pH 7.0) were: CNF (−21 ± 2 mV); TEMPO-CNF (−44 ± 2 mV); CNC (−23± 4mV). Characterization of nanomaterials has been widely published in literature [16,24–26].
Argo corn starch (100% pure) and whole milk (3.33% fat and 3.33% protein content) were purchased from a local grocery store. Digestive components including α-amylase from porcine pancreas (A3176, 12 U/mg), pepsin from porcine gastric mucosa (P7000, 479 U/mg), bile extract porcine (B8631), lipase from porcine pancreas (Type II, L3126, 398 U/mg), pancreatin from porcine pancreas (P1750), and mucin from porcine stomach (Type II, M2378, bound sialic acid 0.4%) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Co. (St. Louis, MO). Other chemicals (including copper (II) acetate monohydrate, zinc sulfate heptahydrate, silver nitrate, ferrous sulfate 7-hydrate, magnesium chloride and calcium chloride dihydrate) were purchased from Fisher Scientific (Pittsburgh, PA) or Sigma-Aldrich.

sections.heading: 2.2. Effect of nanocellulose on in vitro digestion of starch
sections.text:
In vitro digestion of starchwith andwithout the presence of TEMPOCNF or CNC was studied using similar procedures as described in Liu et al. [15] where the effects of CNF and cellulose on in vitro digestion of starch were determined. The differences between the method used in this study and the “standardized method” described by Minekus et al. [27] were shown in Table S1 (in the supplementarymaterial). Specifically, gelatinized corn starch of 5% (w/v) was prepared by dispersing starch in sodium phosphate buffer (PBS, 100 mM) in an Erlenmeyer flask, boiling for 5 min with continuous stirring, and cooling at room temperature with stirring applied as well. 25 mL of fiber solution was added to 5 g of 5% (w/v) corn starch and mixed well before the experiment. The initial 25 mL of fiber solution contained several concentrations of TEMPO-CNF (0.13%, 0.26% and 0.95% (w/w)) or CNC (0.26%, 2.64%, 5.28% and 10.56% (w/w)). Different concentrations of nanocellulose (NC) suspension were prepared by diluting the stock NC with DI water. A control experiment was also performed without the addition of fiber. The samples were held at 37 °C in a shaking water bath (Model 290400S, Boekel Scientific, USA) prior to in vitro digestion.
Salivary digestion was initiated via the addition of 6 mL of ‘salivary juice’ to the initial fiber-starch system. The ‘salivary juice’ is consisted of 0.1 wt% mucin and 0.2 wt% α-amylase in a buffered solution. The digesta pH was quickly adjusted to 6.8 ± 0.2, followed by incubation
at 37 °C with a rotation speed of 100 rpm for 5 min. Gastric digestion was performed after the salivary phase via the addition of ‘gastric juice’ (12 mL) composed of 0.5 wt% pepsin and 0.6 wt% mucin in buffered solution. The pH of digesta was then adjusted to 3.0 ± 0.1 and incubated for 2 h at 37 °C (100 rpm). Intestinal digestion (37 °C, 100 rpm, 2 h) was carried out afterwards, with the addition of 12 mL ‘intestinal juice’ and 6mL ‘bile juice’, followed by pH adjustment to 7.0± 0.2. Specifically, the intestinal juice was consisted of 0.3 wt% lipase and 1.8 wt% pancreatin, while the bile juice contained 6 wt% of bile.
To independently study the effects of fiber on starch digestion and glucose diffusion, the in vitro digestion was conducted both with and without dialysis tubings. In the former, intestinal digestion was performed by placing digesta inside dialysis tubings with a molecular weight cutoff (MWCO) of 12,000–14,000 Da (Spectra/Por 4 RC Dialysis Membrane Tubing, Spectrum Laboratories, Los Angeles, CA) against 0.1M PBS (pH 7.4) (inside and outside volume ratio of 1:12.5). Aliquots of 1.5 mLwere taken from the dialysate and analyzed for the amount of glucose diffused. In the latter, for digesta containing TEMPO-CNF, 300 μL aliquots were taken at time intervals and 150 μL 0.3 M sodium carbonate was added to terminate the reaction. For digesta containing CNC, 300 μL aliquots were taken followed by inactivation of enzyme at 95 °C for 5 min. The sample aliquots were then centrifuged at 6000g for 5 min after which the amount of glucose in the supernatant was determined by using the GOPOD glucose assay kit (Megazyme International Ireland, Bray, Ireland). At the intestinal phase, the final fiber concentrationswere TEMPO-CNF (0.05%, 0.1% and 0.36% (w/w)) or CNC (0.1%, 1%, 2% and 4% (w/w)). Results were reported as the amount of glucose diffused and% starch hydrolyzed at thesefinalNC concentrations for digestion with and without the dialysis tubing, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.3. Rheological measurements of starch digesta containing nanocellulose
sections.text: The viscosity of intestinal digesta containing TEMPO-CNF or CNC was measured according to the method described in Liu & Kong [16]. Specifically, a Discovery HR-2 rheometer (TA instruments, Newcastle, DE) equipped with a 4-blade rotor vane (42 mm in length and 28 mm in diameter) was used for the measurement. Viscous properties of the samples were measured at 37 °C with a pre-shear of 40 s−1 for 2 min, followed by a flow ramp test over a shear rate range of 1–100 s−1. The ratewas increased over a 180 s periodwith a sampling interval of 3 s/pt.

sections.heading: 2.4. In vitro digestion of milk with nanocellulose addition
2.4.1. In vitro digestion of milk protein containing nanocellulose
sections.text: In vitro digestion of milk protein with and without the addition of nanocellulose was performed according to Liu & Kong [16] withmodifications. The initial fiber-milk systems included 6 mL of milk and 21 mL of nanocellulose suspension (0.70% (w/w) CNF, TEMPO-CNF or CNC). In addition, 0.70% (w/w) cellulose (C6288, Sigma) suspension (prepared by dispersing in water) was studied as a comparison. A control sample was also prepared that contained no added fiber. In vitro digestion of milk with or without the addition of fiber was performed as described in Section 2.2, except that after the addition of intestinal (12mL) and bile juice (6mL), the digesta was placed inside a dialysis tubing (8 kDa, Spectra/Por 6 Dialysis tubing, Spectrum Laboratories, Los Angeles, CA) against 0.1 M PBS (pH 7.4) (with an inside and outside volume ratio of 1:12.5), and incubated for 2 h. Aliquots (4 mL) were collected from outside the tubing at time intervals and the amount of free amino nitrogen (FAN) in aliquots was determined by using the o-phthaldialdehyde/N-acetyl-L-cysteine (NOPA) method [28]. During intestinal digestion, the concentration for all fibers (CNF, TEMPO-CNF, CNC and cellulose) was 0.30% (w/w). Results were presented based on the amount of FAN diffusion with respect to each fiber.

sections.heading: 2.4.2. In vitro digestion of milk fat containing nanocellulose
sections.text:
Salivary and gastric digestion of milk fat with and without the addition of fiber solution were carried out similarly as described above, except that the intestinal digestion was performed according to Qin et al. [29] with modifications. No pancreatin was added to the intestinal juice in the digestion of milk fat since oil-in-water lipid emulsions tended to flocculate in the presence of pancreatin during pH-stat in vitro digestion [30].
The initial fiber-milk systems (20.5 g) included 4.5 g milk and 0.70% (w/w) nanocellulose solution (CNF, TEMPO-CNF or CNC). Similarly, 0.70% (w/w) cellulose solution was prepared and used as a comparison. The samples were held at 37 °C in a shaking water bath prior to in vitro digestion. A control sample was also prepared without the addition of fiber.
Salivary digestion (pH 6.8± 0.2, 5 min) was initiated with the addition of 6mL ‘salivary juice’, followed by gastric digestion (3.0± 0.1, 2 h) with the addition of 12 mL ‘gastric juice’. Following the gastric phase, bile (54 mg/mL) and salt solution (0.25 M CaCl2 and 3.75 M NaCl) in 5 mM PBS (pH 7.0) were added to the milk digesta with a volume of 4.5 mL and 1.925 mL, respectively, with the pH of the mixture adjusted to 7.00. Lipase solution (24mg/mL in PBS) was prepared aswell and pH adjusted to 7.0. Intestinal digestion was initiated by the addition of 3.2 mL lipase solution to the mixture and incubated at 37 °C (100 rpm) for 2 h. The amount of free fatty acid (FFA) produced during intestinal digestionwas titratedwith the addition of 0.5M standardized sodium hydroxide (NaOH) while the pH of the digesta was kept constant at 7.0. The amount of NaOH needed to neutralize the amount of FFA released during intestinal digestion was recorded over time and used to calculate the amount of FFA released using the formula:
NFFA ¼ VNaOH CNaOH ð1Þ
whereNFFA is the amount of FFA released (μmol), CNaOH is the concentration of NaOH used (mol/L), and VNaOH is the amount of NaOH added (μL).
Aliquots (100 μL) from samples at the initial phase as well as after gastric and intestinal digestion phases were collected and used for analysis. The final digesta contained ~10 mM CaCl2, ~160 mM NaCl, 1.6 mg/mL lipase and 5 mg/mL bile. Due to the addition of digestive juices, thefinalfiber concentrationwas 0.30% (w/w) for all the trials. Results were reported with respect to each fiber.

sections.heading: 2.5. Microstructural characterization of milk digesta containing nanocellulose
sections.text:
The microstructure of milk digesta containing nanocellulose/cellulose during each digestion phase (samples in Section 2.4.2) was characterized by a Zeiss LSM710 confocal microscope system, according to Liu & Kong [16] with modifications. A 63× (oil) objective lens was used for image capture. Solutions of thefluorescent dyeNile Red (0.1% (w/v) dissolved in absolute ethanol), fast green (0.1% (w/v) dissolved in water) andfluorescent brightener 28 (0.1% (w/v) dissolved inwater)were prepared and used for staining of oil droplets, protein molecules and nanocellulose/cellulose, respectively. Control digesta, as well as digesta containing 1% cellulose, 0.1% CNF, 0.1% TEMPO-CNF and 0.1% CNC during each digestion phase were stained with all the fluorescent dyes at a volume ratio of 200:1:1:1, followed by vortexing for ~5 s to ensure homogeneous staining. A small aliquot (5 μL) of the stained digesta was added to a glass slide with a cover slip on the top. The samples were illuminated at the excitationwavelengths of 543 nm, 633 nmand405 nm for Nile red, fast green and fluorescent brightener 28, respectively. The emission spectra for the three dyes were collected at 592 nm, 698 nm and 441 nm, respectively. Images were analyzed with the software ZEN 2.3 SP1.
2.6. Mineral adsorption capacity of fiber
Themineral adsorption capacity of nanocellulose/cellulose on Cu, Fe, Mg, Ca, Ag and Znwas determined according to themodifiedmethod of Ghodrat et al. [31]. A control experimentwasperformedwithout the addition of fiber. Digestive juices were prepared as described above, except that the addition of CaCl2 and MgCl2 was excluded in the gastric and duodenal juices. A mixture of the mineral solution (concentration 400 ppm for each mineral) was prepared by dissolving the mineral salts in DI water, then the slurry was centrifuged twice at 2860g for 20 min (Hermle Z200A, Labnet International Inc.) to remove insoluble debris, and the supernatant was set to the volume before use. The stock solution was prepared fresh and stored at 4 °C until later use on the same day. 6 mL of mineral solution was added to 21 mL of fiber solution (0.70% (w/w)), followed by the salivary, gastric and intestinal digestion as described in Section 2.4.1. After intestinal digestion, the digesta was centrifuged as described above, and the supernatants were collected, stored at 4 °C overnight and analyzed with inductively coupled plasma–mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) (XSERIES 2 ICP-MS, Thermo Scientific). The mineral adsorption capacity of fiber was calculated by the following formula:
A ¼ C0−C f V m
ð2Þ
where A is the mineral adsorption capacity (μg/g), C0 is the concentration of mineral in the control group (ppm), Cf is the concentration of mineral in the fiber addition group (ppm), V is the volume of digesta (mL), and m is the mass of fiber (g).

sections.heading: 2.7. Statistical analysis
sections.text: Triplicatemeasurementswere performed for all parameters and significant analysis was performed by Duncan's multiple comparison tests with SAS/STAT software (SAS Institute Inc., Cary, NC)with p=0.05. Regression models generated in the graphs were done using Origin data analysis and graphing software.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
3.1. Effects of fiber on starch digestion and glucose diffusion
The effects of TEMPO-CNF or CNC on starch digestion are shown in Figs. 1(a) and 2(a), while the influence of the two NC on glucose diffusion is shown in Figs. 1(b) and 2(b) respectively. Results from Figs. 1 (a) and 2(a) show that the addition of TEMPO-CNF or CNC at any concentration tested did not cause any significant differences on the amount of glucose released, though lower initial glucose release rates (calculated based on the slopes of the curves in the first 10 min digestion, as shown in the inserted figures of Figs. 1(a) and 2(a)) were observed with the presence of higher NC (TEMPO-CNF/CNC) concentrations. Results from Figs. 1(b) and 2(b) show that 0.36% (w/ w) TEMPO-CNF or 2–4% (w/w) CNC addition caused significantly less amount of glucose diffusion. In addition, 0.1–0.36% (w/w) TEMPO-CNF and 1–4% (w/w) CNC addition resulted in lower initial glucose diffusion rates than that of control, as shown in the Figs. 1(b) and 2(b).
Results shown here are similar to that reported in Liu et al. [15] where cellulose or CNF did not cause any significant effects on starch digestion, but high concentrations of CNF significantly reduced the amount of glucose diffusion. The findings show similar phenomena as well as mechanisms of three types of NC in terms of their effects on starch digestion and glucose diffusion. However, our findings are different from those reported in literature [18,19] that nanocellulose significantly reduced starch digestion. The disagreement may be due to the differences in testing methodology. Specifically, in this study, CNC was added to gelatinized starch with sequential simulated digestion trials
performed, while in other studies, CNC and starch were pre-mixed before starch gelatinization. According toNsor-Atindana et al. [19], the addition of CNC to whey protein isolate-starch system prior to heating at 70 °C led to increased digesta viscosity as well as decreased glucose release and glucose diffusion. Moreover, this effect was more substantial in CNC with larger aspect ratios. Similarly, Ji et al. [18] carried out a study by mixing CNC with starch prior to the gelatinization process and found that 0.2% CNC addition reduced starch digestibility. Therefore, it maybe deducible that CNC influenced starch gelatinization process, then delayed the subsequent starch digestion; however, CNC may not play a significant role on the digestion of gelatinized starch.

sections.heading: 3.2. Rheological measurement of starch digesta containing nanocellulose
sections.text:
Our previous study [15] show that the effects of CNF on starch digestion and glucose diffusionweremainly due to high viscosity achieved at high fiber concentrations. Therefore, the intestinal viscosity of digesta containing various concentrations of TEMPO-CNF or CNC was studied and shown in Fig. 3(a) and (b). Moreover, the glucose diffusion rate was plotted against intestinal viscosity of digesta at 20 s−1 to explore their relationship.
Fig. 3(a) and (b) shows that the apparent viscosity of digesta containing TEMPO-CNF or CNC increased with higher NC concentrations. This is similar to that reported in Liu et al. [15] where the apparent viscosity of CNF was a cubic function of its concentration, which is due to the increased effective volume in the suspension at higher concentrations. Moreover, Fig. 3(c) and (d) shows that glucose diffusion rates decreased with the increase in viscosity of digesta containing these two anionic NC. This is also similar to that reported in Liu et al. [15] where higher viscosity of CNF resulted in lower glucose diffusion rates. In addition to viscosity, other factors such as glucose adsorption capacity of fiber may also contribute to reduced glucose diffusion [15,32].

The effect of different types of nanocellulose or cellulose on free amino nitrogen (FAN) release is plotted in Fig. 4(b). Results show that the addition of 0.3% (w/w) CNC caused significantly lower amount of FAN diffusion during intestinal digestion, while the addition of other fibers (cellulose, CNF or TEMPO-CNF) did not cause any significant differences from control. The results shown here are similar to that of our previous study [16], where the addition of CNC caused significantly lower amount of FAN diffusion during intestinal digestion of whey protein isolate (WPI). Moreover, CNC at high concentrations could significantly reduce the amount of FAN released. There existed electrostatic interaction between WPI and TEMPO-CNF/CNC at the gastric phase, resulting in decreased mean particle size as well as digesta viscosity. But different to CNC, TEMPO-CNF formed aggregates at the gastric phase and caused phase separation [16]. It seems that the effect of CNC on delayed FAN diffusion is mainly due to the non-electrostatic interaction betweenWPI and CNC instead of viscosity, since our previous study [16] showed that the intestinal viscosity of protein digesta containing CNF (0.30% (w/w)) at the 20 s−1 shear rate was larger than that of CNC (0.30% (w/w)). Combining the results of Fig. 4(a) and (b), it can be concluded that the addition of CNF and TEMPO-CNF significantly delayed initialmilk fat digestion,while the addition of CNC significantly reduced the amount of free amino nitrogen diffusion.

sections.heading: 3.4. Microstructural characterization of milk digesta containing nanocellulose
sections.text:
Confocal microscopy images of milk digesta containing nanocellulose or cellulose are shown in Fig. 5, where fat globules are shown as red, protein globules as pink and NC as blue. For the control (milk only) sample at the initial phase (Fig. 5A1), small fat and protein globules were observed. After gastric digestion, large flocs were observed in the control (Fig. 5A2). Similarly, flocculation of milk protein stabilized lipid emulsions was observed during in vitro gastric digestion and the flocs remained during the entire gastric process [33]. Increase in mean particle size ofmilk protein after gastric digestionwas also shown in our previous study [16]. Itwas reported that coagulation ofmilk could occur during gastric digestion, since pepsin could destabilize casein
micelles and acid coagulation of casein could occur [34]. As milk fat is stabilized by milk protein, after moving to the gastric phase, milk fat droplets were destabilized as well. Clot formations (with caseins and fat globules) were also observed by Ye et al. [34] after gastric digestion of milk using an in vitro dynamic model. At the intestinal phase, larger flocs of milk digesta were still observed (Fig. 5A3). On one hand, during pH-stat digestion of milk, protein globules were not digested due to the absence of pancreatin. On theother hand, some digestion productswere generated during intestinal digestion of lipid droplets, including undigested lipid droplets, calcium soaps, micelles and biopolymer complexes [35].
For milk digesta containing cellulose or CNF, no morphological changes of fiber were observed at all three digestion phases (Fig. 5B1– B3, C1–C3). Large flocs were observed after gastric and intestinal digestion in samples with cellulose and CNF addition (Fig. 5B2–B3 and C2– C3). However, in milk digesta containing anionic NC (TEMPO-CNF or CNC), no flocs were observed (Fig. 5D2–E2). Instead, binding of protein/lipid globules to anionic NC was shown, especially in milk digesta containing CNC. The binding between anionic NC and milk protein at the gastric phase was also found in our previous study [16]. The electrostatic interaction between anionic NC and positively charged protein at the gastric phase reduced the aggregation of milk protein at this phase. Similarly, Moue'coucou et al. [36] reported that the effect of anionic fibers on proteolysis at the gastric phase was mainly due to electrostatic attractions between oppositely charged protein and fibers at the gastric pH, though non-electrostatic interaction (including hydrogen bonding) may also occur.
Milk digesta containing TEMPO-CNF showed dense aggregates of TEMPO-CNF gel after gastric digestion (Fig. 5D2). Large dense aggregates of TEMPO-CNF were also observed after intestinal digestion (Fig. 5D3). The formation of TEMPO-CNF aggregates at the gastric phase was also observed in our previous study [16]. Other studies proved that aggregation of TEMPO-CNF in the form of heterogeneous clumps and de-swelled gel occurred under conditions of salt addition and low pH (b3.0) [37,38]. Reductions in electrostatic repulsion as well as dimerization between carboxyl groups are two proposed reasons for the aggregation phenomenon [38–40].

The binding betweenmilk protein and anionic NC was not observed at the intestinal phase (Fig. 5D3–E3). Larger hydrogel network of CNC was observed at the intestinal phase (Fig. 5E3) than that at the gastric phase (Fig. 5E2). This may be due to the higher ionic strength at the intestinal phase than that at the gastric phase. Larger flocs of protein globules and fat (or fat digestion products) were also observed in digesta containing CNC at the intestinal phase (Fig. 5E3) than that at the gastric phase (Fig. 5E2).
3.5. Mineral adsorption capacity of fiber
Results in Table 1 show that themineral adsorption capacity offibers tested were all below 300 μg/g. The amount of mineral (Ca, Cu, Mg, Zn) adsorbed by nanocellulose/cellulose after sequential simulated digestion in this study was different than that by wheat bran, rice bran and oat fiber under simple mixing conditions (i.e., fibers added to mineral solution with shaking applied) [41]. There existed some variations among minerals adsorbed by different fibers as shown in Table 1. The extents of mineral binding by fibers depend on the nature and chemical composition of fiber as well as the mineral type [42]. It was shown that different fibers possess different number of binding sites and affinity for minerals [43]. Furthermore, competitive interactions among minerals may also affect their binding with fibers [44].
Table 1 also shows that all three types of NC could adsorb significant amount of Fe but not other minerals. The interactions between dietary fiber (including lemon peel and pulp, aswell as pomaces generated during the production of white wine, cider and olive oil) and Fe(II)/Fe(III) have also been reported by other researchers [42]. It was reported that maize andwheatfibers could decrease ferrous iron retention by binding with ferrous ions, promoting ferrous ion autoxidation aswell as forming poorly soluble iron polymers [45]. However, there was no evidence of bonding between iron and cellulose and only adsorption of iron to cellulose surface was observed [46,47]. The reason for the significantly higher amount of iron adsorption by NC than cellulose may be that NC has smaller diameter and larger specific surface area.
Moreover, Table 1 show that TEMPO-CNF adsorbed more calcium than otherfibers at the endof intestinal digestion even thoughno significant differences were observed among sample groups. This may be because tight binding could form between carboxyl groups and calcium ions [48]. It was reported that the uptake of calcium ions by cellulosic materials followed an ion exchange mechanism (electrostatic interaction) that is limited by the carboxyl content of the cellulosic materials [49]. Specifically, when carboxyl containing fibers interact with metal ions, metal ions could replace hydrogen from carboxylic groups [49]. Moreover, it was shown that calcium ions could dissociate the complexes formed between BSA and alginate (containing carboxyl groups) [48]. Based on the results in Table 1, cellulose, CNF or CNCdid not adsorb significant amount of calcium, which is similar to that reported by Luccia & Kunkel [44] where the authors reported no binding of exogenous calcium by cellulose, methylcellulose or psyllium. In addition, it was shown in literature that the calciumadsorption capacity of cellulose was the lowest among 18 fibers [50]. In addition, Table 1 show that TEMPO-CNF adsorbed slightly higher amount of magnesium than other fibers though no significant differences were observed. The calcium and magnesium adsorption capacity of fiber was considered to be related to water/oil holding capacity or particle density [50], but
not particle size [51]. Therefore, the differences among fibers in the calcium and magnesium adsorption capacity in this study may be related to both the carboxylate content and water holding capacity/particle density of fiber.
Results from Table 1 show that the copper adsorption capacity of TEMPO-CNF or cellulose at the end of intestinal digestion was similar with values of 11–15 μg/g. Table 1 also show that CNC adsorbed zinc while other fibers tested showed much lower affinity. According to Nawirska [52], the amount of Zn or Cu bound by cellulose fractions from apple pomace, rosehip, chokeberry and pear pomace were small (b150 μg/g). Different trends have been observed in themineral adsorption capacity of NC under simulated physiological conditions of the small intestine as compared to that under simple mixture conditions (i.e., fibers added to mineral solution with shaking applied). For example, under simple mixture conditions, the copper adsorption capacity of TEMPO-CNF (135 mg/g) was ten-fold larger than that of native CNF [53]. The adsorption of copper ions to TEMPO-CNF was found to increase with pH and carboxylate content (i.e., degree of oxidation) [53]. Similarly, under simple mixture conditions, regardless of surface functionality of NC, the metal ion selectivity was Ag(I) N Fe(III) N Cu(II) [54]. However, in our study, under simulated physiological conditions of the small intestine, such trend of selectivity was not observed. In addition, it was shown that under simple mixture conditions, wheat and barley had higher affinity for iron than copper and zinc ions [31]. However, following sequential simulated digestion, wheat bran had higher adsorption capacity of copper than that of iron or zinc [46]. Moreover, under simple mixture conditions, the silver ion adsorption capacity of CNC (34.4 mg/g, corresponding to 64% adsorption) was higher than that of CNF (27%) [55]. The sorption phenomenon was pH dependent, and electrostatic interaction was considered to be themain mechanism of heavy metal ion adsorption on NC. CNC with more negative charges could adsorb more positively charged heavy metal ions [55]. At pH 3.5–4.5, the silver ion adsorption capacity of carboxylated CNC was similar to that of sulfonated CNC [54]. In this study, under simulated physiological conditions of the small intestine, the amount of Ag adsorbed by CNC was slightly higher than that by CNF and cellulose, however, TEMPO-CNF did not show adsorption. This may be because in the presence of mixedmetal ions, TEMPO-CNF had higher affinity towards calcium and magnesium than silver. Nonetheless, no significant differences were observed in the silver adsorption capacity among the three NC.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
Anionic NC (TEMPO-CNF or CNC) did not show any significant effects on the amount of glucose release, but both anionic NC at high concentrations caused significant reductions in the amount of glucose diffusion, especially at 0.36% (w/w) TEMPO-CNF and 2–4% (w/w) CNC. In addition, CNF and TEMPO-CNF at 0.3% (w/w) significantly reduced the amount of free fatty acid released during intestinal digestion of milk fat, while CNC with a concentration of 0.3% (w/w) delayed diffusion of free amino nitrogen (FAN) during intestinal digestion of milk protein. The effect of CNF and TEMPO-CNF on lower amount of FFA releasewas thought to be associatedwith the increase in digesta viscosity, while the effect of CNC on delayed diffusion of FAN was thought to be due to its interaction with milk protein. It was also found that all three types of NC adsorbed significant amount of Fe though with values b300 μg/g, while the adsorption of other minerals (Ca, Mg, Zn, Cu and Ag) was not significant with values b150 μg/g except the adsorption of Zn by CNC. Overall, this study indicates that three types of NCmay affect digestion and absorption of foods containing carbohydrates, lipids, proteins and minerals, if incorporated into food or supplements as a fiber source.

metadata.abstractText: Article history: Received 30 May 2019 Received in revised form 18 June 2019 Accepted 24 June 2019 Available online 02 July 2019 Three types of nanocellulose, namely nano-fibrilated cellulose (NFC, also called cellulose nano-fibrils (CNF)), TEMPO (2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl radical) oxidized cellulose nano-fibrils (TEMPO-CNF), and nanocrystalline cellulose (NCC, also called cellulose nano-crystals (CNC)), were studied in terms of their effects on in vitromilk digestion andmineral adsorption. The effects of anionic NC (TEMPO-CNF and CNC) on in vitro starch digestion and glucose diffusion were also investigated. Results show that TEMPO-CNF and CNC at high concentrations caused significant reductions in glucose diffusion, especially at 0.36% (w/w) TEMPO-CNF and 2–4% (w/ w) CNC. In addition, CNF and TEMPO-CNF at 0.30% (w/w) significantly reduced the amount of free fatty acid produced during intestinal digestion ofmilk fat. CNC at a concentration of 0.3% (w/w)delayed diffusion of free amino nitrogen during intestinal digestion of milk protein. All three types of NC adsorbed significant amount of Fe, and CNC adsorbed significant amount of Zn, while no significant adsorption was observed on otherminerals (Ca, Mg, Zn, Cu and Ag). Results from this study suggest that all three types of NC, when incorporated in food or supplements as zero-calorie fiber, may affect food digestion and nutrient absorption. © 2019 Elsevier B.V.
